If $a,b,c$ are integers from the set of positive integers less than $7$ such that \begin{align*}
abc&\equiv 1\pmod 7,\\
5c&\equiv 2\pmod 7,\\
6b&\equiv 3+b\pmod 7,
\end{align*}then what is the remainder when $a+b+c$ is divided by $7$?
inference:
Solution:
From the third congruence, we have $5b\equiv 3\pmod7$ and so $b\equiv 3\pmod 7$.

From the second congruence, we have $c\equiv 2\pmod 7$.

Substituting these values into the first congruence, we get $a(3)(2)\equiv 1\pmod 7$, and so $a\equiv 4\pmod 7$.

Therefore, $a+b+c\equiv 4+3+2\equiv 0\pmod 7$.
